author: alexssd7fp
content: Upon researching, indeed, core developers rarely discuss tokenomics, especially when the topic is controversial (i.e., making a reward reduction for someone), as they appear to be extremely careful not to say something that may cause cascading disagreements and protests (like what was with EIP-1559).

author: alexssd7fp
content:
# Part 1 - EIP-1559

The most heated and controversial change was EIP-1559, and most of the time, I will talk about this EIP here. Initially, it was proposed in early-mid 2019, but it is visible that no definitive action regarding actual implementation was done, after which it was somewhat forgotten until the spring of next year, which is *shortly* after Tim Beiko from Consensys joined. After that happened, we can see the work effort quickly escalated, with the first serious ACD discussions sparking, the series of EIP-1559 implementers' calls launched, and all that happened rapidly. Originally, there was little mention of fee burn and almost no evidence that suggests that the original introduction of EIP-1559 was made primarily because of the fee burn; however, later, we can see that it got picked up because of that.

author: alexssd7fp
content: Initially, most of the publicity was attracted to EIP-1559 because it was believed that it would reduce fees. It was not uncommon to see "EIP-1559 fixes high gas fees" from many people on social media platforms like Twitter, Reddit, and others. That continued to be the case closely through 2020-2021, with the visible efforts to increase the awareness of this misconception being visible closer to mid-2021 only. My opinion on this is that it suggests the omission of efforts to destroy this misconception might have been intentional, as when things are "almost done", it is almost impossible to make any structural changes which would require rewriting the implementation.

author: alexssd7fp
content: In early 2021, miners protested the EIP-1559 fee burn, demanding action from core developers - either removing the fee burn or increasing the reward to compensate for it. Initially, Tim Beiko and core developers seemed to care, and they even hosted an EIP-1559 Community Call in February 2021 and opened EIP-1559-related discussion channels in the R&D Discord server. However, although core developers provided visible efforts, no definite action was made to address this issue to make miners happy; there was not even a 10% static block reward increase. This indirectly suggests how important the fee burn was in EIP-1559 and low miner rewards in general.

author: alexssd7fp
content: Closer to mid-2021, after the common misconception that EIP-1559 is for reducing fees was effectively eliminated, there was a new "wave" of what seemed to be marketing that Ethereum is "ultra-sound money" and that Ethereum is going to be deflationary, which will (openly) make the price go up. While there is no evidence suggesting the firms that manage the core development are related to this, this fact still deserves mention.

author: alexssd7fp
content:
# Part 2 - Investors

Many companies participate in core development, but the most notable are the Ethereum Foundation (the official foundation company of Ethereum) and Consensys. While the EF is funded with premine, Consensys is funded by VCs.

author: alexssd7fp
content: While there is little motivation for EF to be focused on the price reaction when making core development decisions (although arguably there is, to sell their premined ETH for higher), Consensys definitely does have since it's a for-profit company. Consensys is a large player in Ethereum that no one is discussing, while this firm appears to be behind the actions mentioned above. Looking at their financials, they live off investment rounds (with the last Series D funding, collectively raised US$450M of investment funds from large private venture capital firms). They are technically not a "regular" company, and they do not make any profit directly. Instead, they are investing in projects around the Ethereum ecosystem and account for a significant contribution to the Ethereum protocol development itself. Sometimes, their level of control gets comparable to the EF's (Ethereum Foundation), the go-to company to refer to as "Ethereum". We do not need to be geniuses to understand that VCs who invest in Consensys are here for profit; this is not altruism. And think for a bit, what is the way how investing money into Ethereum can be profitable? The answer lies right in front of us - to profit off the Ethereum adoption, which is directly related to ETH price.

author: alexssd7fp
content: While EF was the only company doing core development before 2019-2020, Consensys has started its growth of control since then and grown into the most influential company in the Ethereum space after EF, closely following the latter. Combined, investors account for all governance that happens behind Consensys as a whole, and they are the entities who make the decisions that collectively represent the decisions of Consensys as a company â€” and these decisions are made **for profit** (this is important).

author: alexssd7fp
content: Core developers themselves need to get funded to finance their work, and since the software they provide is freeware, there must be an external source of cash flow. It does appear that a vast majority (95%+) of that are investments, and it's in the name - they are made for profit. Now ask yourself a question, what's the only way to finance core development? The only reasonable answer that can be provided is to buy ETH low, work on it, and sell ETH high. Hence, while directly Ethereum core development has nothing to do with tokenomics, indirectly, it's as related as it can ever be.

author: alexssd7fp
content:
And I do agree with you, Micah. Indirectly, the employees of companies (the faces of it) that do core development on Ethereum have no relation to the Ethereum price, but the decisions and commands instructed to them are directly related. Look beyond the "visible bubble" of Ethereum core development (and arguably the governance too).

# Conclusion

I think I have provided enough information here. There is a lot more, however. It was only a brief write-up on this. All these facts suggest that, albeit indirectly, core development decisions are heavily related to tokenomics and Ethereum price in general. Now think about it closely. Provided all of this has happened combined, it is either a rare coincidence or behind-the-scenes core developer coordination, which is not public, unlike the discussions we have here.
